depth_guidance.deep: Full migration cartography: all concept movements traced with mechanisms, intermediate stops, contextual analysis of origin and destination, assessment of what survived transit and what was lost, and comparison of the author's migration patterns (do they tend to cite, borrow silently, or absorb unconsciously?)
depth_guidance.standard: Map migration paths with mechanisms of travel, contextual differences between origin and destination, and assessment of whether the migration preserved or transformed the concept
depth_guidance.surface: List the 3-5 most obvious concept migrations with origin and destination

analytical_dimensions.description: Where did concepts move? Map the journey of each key concept from its location in the prior work to its location in the current work. A concept's migration path includes not just origin and destination but the mechanism of travel: was it explicitly cited, silently borrowed, independently rediscovered, or unconsciously absorbed?
probing_questions: Which concepts from the prior work appear in the current work?
How did each concept travel -- explicit citation, silent borrowing, or unconscious absorption?
Did concepts migrate directly, or through intermediate works?
Were concepts transplanted whole, or did only fragments survive the journey?
What was the context of origin and the context of arrival -- how different are they?

depth_guidance.deep: Full mutation analysis: every semantic change catalogued with type, degree, directionality, motivation (strategic vs. drift), relationship to vocabulary/methodology/metaphor/framing changes from concept_evolution, and patterns across mutations (does the author tend toward certain mutation types?)
depth_guidance.standard: Map mutations with type classification, before/after meanings, evidence from both texts, and assessment of whether mutations were strategic or accidental
depth_guidance.surface: Identify the most significant semantic mutations with before/after meanings

analytical_dimensions.description: How did meaning change during migration? When a concept moves from one work to another, it undergoes semantic mutation. The mutation may be extension (broadening), restriction (narrowing), metaphorization (becoming figurative), distortion (warping), or inversion (meaning the opposite). Each mutation type has different implications for genealogical analysis.
probing_questions: For each migrated concept, what changed in its meaning?
What type of mutation occurred -- extension, restriction, metaphorization, distortion, inversion?
Was the mutation gradual or sudden? Acknowledged or concealed?
Does the mutation serve the argument (strategic) or appear accidental (drift)?
How does the mutation relate to the dimensional changes identified by concept_evolution?

depth_guidance.deep: Full appropriation analysis: every borrowing catalogued with fidelity classification, purpose analysis, legitimacy assessment, impact on both the original and new context, and patterns of appropriation (does the author tend to appropriate faithfully or creatively?)
depth_guidance.standard: Map appropriations with relationship-to-original classification, evidence for each, assessment of whether the appropriation is legitimate or questionable, and the new purpose served
depth_guidance.surface: Identify the most obvious appropriations with original and new purpose

analytical_dimensions.description: What was borrowed, and how was it used? Appropriation goes beyond mere migration: it involves taking a concept and making it serve a new purpose. The appropriation may be faithful (preserving the original intent), adapted (modifying for new context), distorted (warping beyond recognition), or inverted (using against its original purpose). In self-genealogy, authors appropriate from their own past selves.
probing_questions: What concepts were appropriated from the prior work for new purposes?
Is each appropriation faithful, adapted, distorted, or inverted relative to the original?
What new purpose does the appropriated concept serve?
Does the appropriation strengthen or weaken the original concept?
Is the author aware of the appropriation, or do they present borrowed material as new?

depth_guidance.deep: Full distortion analysis: every distortion catalogued with type, degree, motivation, beneficiary, impact assessment, and counterfactual (what changes if the distortion is corrected). Assessment of whether distortion patterns reveal systematic bias in how the author relates to their own past work
depth_guidance.standard: Map distortions with type, original vs. distorted meaning, evidence, likely motivation, and impact on the current argument

analytical_dimensions.description: How were ideas warped in transit? Distortion is a specific and important form of semantic mutation: the concept is not just changed but degraded -- oversimplified, strawmanned, selectively quoted, or inverted. In self-genealogy, distortion reveals interesting dynamics: an author may distort their own earlier positions to make current positions look more novel or more consistent than they are.
probing_questions: Are any concepts from the prior work distorted in the current work?
What type of distortion -- oversimplification, strawmanning, selective quotation, inversion?
Who benefits from the distortion -- does it serve the current argument?
Is the distortion likely intentional (strategic) or unintentional (forgetting, drift)?
How would the current argument change if the distortion were corrected?

depth_guidance.deep: Full recombination analysis: all identifiable recombinations catalogued with source elements traced to specific prior works, novelty assessment, tension analysis, acknowledgment status, and evaluation of the author's recombinatory style (are they a synthesizer, a bricoleur, a system-builder?)
depth_guidance.standard: Map recombinations with source elements, the new combination, assessment of genuine novelty vs. rearrangement, and any tensions introduced
depth_guidance.surface: Note any obvious recombinations of prior ideas

analytical_dimensions.description: What new combinations of old ideas have been created? One of the most creative acts in intellectual work is recombination: taking elements from different prior works (or different parts of the same prior work) and combining them into something new. The recombination may produce genuine novelty -- or it may produce the illusion of novelty through rearrangement.
probing_questions: Are ideas from the prior work combined with ideas from other sources in the current work?
Are elements from different parts of the prior work recombined in new ways?
Does the recombination produce genuine novelty or rearrangement?
Are the recombined elements compatible, or does their combination create tensions?
Does the author acknowledge the recombinatory nature of their innovation?

depth_guidance.deep: Full acknowledgment analysis: every borrowing classified as cited/uncited/partially-cited, pattern analysis (what determines citation?), correlation with distortion and appropriation patterns, strategic interpretation of the acknowledgment pattern, and assessment of what the pattern reveals about the author's self-relation
depth_guidance.standard: Map acknowledgment status for each identified borrowing, hypothesize reasons for non-acknowledgment, and assess whether the pattern serves the author's rhetorical goals
depth_guidance.surface: Note whether major borrowings are cited or uncited

analytical_dimensions.description: What is cited and what is suppressed? The politics of self-citation are revealing. Authors choose which prior work to reference and which to leave unmentioned. Cited borrowings assert continuity and build authority. Uncited borrowings may indicate embarrassment, desire for novelty, strategic distancing, or genuine forgetting. The pattern of acknowledgment and suppression is itself genealogical evidence of the first order.
probing_questions: Which borrowings from the prior work are explicitly cited in the current work?
Which borrowings are uncited -- present but unacknowledged?
What pattern explains the acknowledgment decisions -- what is the logic of citation?
Does non-acknowledgment correlate with distortion (suppress what you've warped)?
What would change in how we read the current work if all debts were acknowledged?

depth_scaling.deep: Complete migration cartography including intermediate stops, mechanisms, contextual analysis, assessment of what survived vs. what was lost in transit, and meta-analysis of the author's characteristic migration patterns across their corpus
depth_scaling.standard: Full migration map with mechanisms of travel (cited/silent/absorbed), contextual analysis of origin vs. destination environments, and initial assessment of preservation vs. transformation
depth_scaling.surface: Lists 3-5 most obvious concept migrations with origin and destination locations identified

capabilities.description: Map where concepts moved from the prior work to the current work, including mechanisms of travel and contextual differences
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability maps the journey of concepts from their location in the prior work to their appearance in the current work, attending not merely to presence or absence but to the mechanisms and conditions of travel. Drawing on Derrida's theory of iterability—the principle that every repetition of a sign is also an alteration—it recognizes that when an author re-uses their own concept, they are not simply transporting a stable meaning but re-inscribing it in a new context where it inevitably takes on new valences. The capability distinguishes between explicit citation (where continuity is asserted), silent borrowing (where the debt is concealed), and unconscious absorption (where the author may not recognize their own influence on themselves). Each mechanism reveals different dynamics of self-relation: citation builds authority and continuity, silent borrowing suggests strategic distancing or novelty-seeking, and unconscious absorption points to foundational patterns that operate below the threshold of awareness.

This capability provides the essential infrastructure for all other appropriation analyses. Without mapping where concepts actually moved, we cannot assess how they mutated (semantic_mutations), why they were borrowed (appropriation_patterns), whether they were distorted (distortion_map), or what was cited versus suppressed (acknowledgment_status). It transforms the dimensional comparisons from concept_evolution—which tell us WHAT changed—into a genealogical narrative of transit that tells us HOW and WHY concepts traveled. The sophistication of this capability lies in recognizing that concepts rarely migrate cleanly: they may move in fragments, travel through intermediate works, or arrive disguised under new terminology while retaining their functional role in the argument.
indicators: The current work uses terminology or concepts that closely resemble phrasing from the prior work, but without explicit citation
The author makes claims that depend on arguments previously established in the prior work, creating conceptual dependencies
Key terms appear in both works but with different surrounding vocabulary or argumentative contexts
The current work's structure or methodology echoes approaches developed in the prior work
Footnotes or citations reference the prior work but do not fully capture the extent of conceptual borrowing

intellectual_grounding.method: Derrida's iterability shows that every instance of repetition is constitutively different from what it repeats, because context is never fully determinable or controllable. This capability applies that insight to self-citation: each time an author re-uses their own concept, it is iteration not identity, and the differences that emerge in transit are genealogically revealing.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete mutation analysis cataloguing every semantic change, classifying types, assessing degrees and directionality, relating mutations to concept_evolution's dimensional changes, and identifying patterns in the author's mutation tendencies
depth_scaling.standard: Classifies all major mutations by type (extension/restriction/metaphorization/distortion/inversion) with textual evidence and assessment of strategic vs. drift motivation
depth_scaling.surface: Identifies the most significant semantic mutations with simple before/after meaning descriptions

capabilities.description: Classify how meaning changed during migration -- extension, restriction, metaphorization, distortion, inversion
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability tracks how meaning shifts as concepts move between contexts, recognizing that semantic change is not random drift but patterned transformation that reveals intellectual development, strategic repositioning, or unconscious evolution. It classifies mutations into types—extension (broadening scope), restriction (narrowing application), metaphorization (literalizing or figuralizing), distortion (systematic warping), and inversion (meaning reversal)—because different mutation types have different genealogical implications. A concept that undergoes extension may indicate growing confidence or ambition; one that suffers restriction may reveal the discovery of limits or counterexamples. Metaphorization often signals disciplinary border-crossing (as concepts move from technical to popular registers or vice versa), while inversion suggests fundamental repositioning. The capability distinguishes strategic mutations (serving the current argument's needs) from drift (accidental semantic slippage over time), a distinction central to understanding authorial agency in self-genealogy.

Semantic mutations are the mechanism by which appropriation happens: you cannot assess appropriation fidelity without knowing what semantic changes occurred. This capability builds directly on migration_paths (you must know a concept traveled before you can track how it changed) and feeds into appropriation_patterns (classifying whether borrowings are faithful, adapted, or distorted depends on mutation analysis) and distortion_map (distortion is a severe form of mutation). The sophistication lies in recognizing that mutations are often partial and multi-directional: a concept may be extended in one dimension while restricted in another, or metaphorized for some purposes while remaining literal for others. Tracking these complex mutation patterns reveals the conceptual labor involved in maintaining coherence across works.
indicators: The same term is used in both works but with noticeably different scope or application range
A concept that was literal/technical in the prior work becomes metaphorical/figurative in the current work, or vice versa
The current work defines or explains a concept differently than the prior work did, even if implicitly
Examples or illustrations used for a concept in the current work differ significantly from those in the prior work, suggesting shifted meaning
The concept's relationship to other concepts has changed (what it's opposed to, what it's aligned with, what it presupposes)

intellectual_grounding.method: Bakhtin's heteroglossia demonstrates that words carry multiple, stratified meanings depending on their contexts of use, and that meaning is dialogically constituted through interaction between utterances. This capability treats each re-use of a concept as a dialogic event where the prior meaning encounters the new context, producing semantic mutation through their interaction.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete appropriation analysis cataloguing every borrowing with fidelity classification, purpose analysis, legitimacy and impact assessment for both original and new contexts, and meta-analysis of the author's appropriative style and patterns
depth_scaling.standard: Classifies all major appropriations as faithful/adapted/distorted/inverted with evidence, legitimacy assessment, and analysis of the new purpose served
depth_scaling.surface: Identifies most obvious appropriations with original purpose and new purpose noted

capabilities.description: Assess how borrowed concepts serve new purposes, classifying fidelity and legitimacy
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability assesses how borrowed concepts are put to work in new contexts, evaluating not just that borrowing occurred but the purpose it serves and the fidelity with which it was executed. Drawing on Harold Bloom's anxiety of influence, it recognizes that appropriation is never neutral: authors relate to their sources (including their own prior selves) through complex dynamics of fidelity and deviation, reverence and rebellion. The capability classifies appropriations as faithful (preserving original intent and function), adapted (modified for new context but recognizably continuous), distorted (warped beyond the original's parameters), or inverted (turned against its original purpose). Each classification carries different implications: faithful appropriation suggests cumulative knowledge-building, adaptation indicates contextual sensitivity, distortion may signal forgetting or strategic misreading, and inversion points to fundamental intellectual reorientation. The capability also assesses legitimacy: is the appropriation intellectually honest, does it strengthen or weaken the original concept, and does the author acknowledge the appropriative nature of their move?

This capability synthesizes migration_paths (where concepts moved) and semantic_mutations (how they changed) into a judgment about the character of borrowing. It feeds directly into acknowledgment_status (citation patterns correlate with appropriation fidelity) and provides crucial context for distortion_map (distortion is failed or weaponized appropriation). The sophistication of this capability lies in recognizing that appropriation exists on a spectrum rather than in discrete categories, and that authors appropriate differently from themselves than from others—self-appropriation may be more unconscious, more taken-for-granted, and thus more prone to unacknowledged drift. By cataloguing appropriation patterns across multiple works, the capability reveals an author's characteristic style of self-relation: are they faithful stewards of their own ideas, creative adapters, strategic revisers, or forgetful wanderers?
indicators: A concept from the prior work is applied to a significantly different domain or problem in the current work
The current work uses a concept in ways that seem to stretch or strain its original definition
The function a concept performs in the argument has shifted (e.g., from foundational premise to illustrative example, or vice versa)
The current work selectively emphasizes certain aspects of a prior concept while ignoring others
The concept is embedded in a new argumentative or methodological framework that changes its implications

intellectual_grounding.method: Bloom's theory of poetic influence describes how later poets struggle with their precursors through characteristic misreadings (clinamen, tessera, kenosis, etc.). This capability adapts Bloom's framework to self-influence, recognizing that authors also struggle with their own prior works, appropriating from themselves through similar dynamics of creative misreading, though with different motivations (establishing novelty vs. consistency).

depth_scaling.deep: Complete distortion analysis cataloguing every misrepresentation with type, degree, motivation, beneficiary analysis, impact assessment, counterfactual analysis (what changes if corrected), and pattern analysis revealing systematic biases in the author's self-relation
depth_scaling.standard: Maps all identifiable distortions with type classification (oversimplification/strawmanning/selective quotation/inversion), evidence from both texts, likely motivation (strategic vs. forgetting), and impact on current argument
depth_scaling.surface: Notes any obvious distortions where current representation clearly mismatches prior work's actual position

capabilities.description: Identify where concepts were degraded in transit -- oversimplified, strawmanned, selectively quoted, or inverted
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability identifies cases where concepts from the prior work have been degraded, simplified, or warped in ways that misrepresent their original form and function. Distortion is a specific and particularly revealing form of semantic mutation: it involves not just change but damage to the concept's integrity. Drawing on Said's concept of traveling theory, which shows how ideas become vulgarized or domesticated as they move between contexts, this capability recognizes that authors can distort their own earlier work—sometimes strategically (to make current positions appear more novel or more consistent than they are), sometimes unconsciously (through forgetting, simplification, or selective memory). The capability classifies distortion types: oversimplification (reducing complexity to a slogan), strawmanning (presenting the prior position in its weakest form), selective quotation (cherry-picking passages that support current views), and inversion (attributing to the prior work a position it explicitly rejected). Each distortion type suggests different genealogical dynamics: oversimplification may indicate popularization or impatience with nuance, strawmanning suggests anxiety about past commitments, selective quotation reveals strategic reading, and inversion points to repressed tensions.

Distortion analysis depends on semantic_mutations (distortion is severe mutation) but adds a normative dimension: not just how meaning changed but whether it was degraded. This capability feeds into appropriation_patterns (distorted appropriations are illegitimate) and acknowledgment_status (authors may suppress what they've distorted). The sophistication lies in distinguishing intentional from unintentional distortion—a distinction that requires assessing whether the distortion serves the current argument's rhetorical needs. The capability also performs counterfactual analysis: how would the current argument change if the distortion were corrected? This reveals what the distortion accomplishes and whether the current position depends on misrepresenting the past. Patterns of distortion across multiple works reveal systematic biases in how an author relates to their intellectual history.
indicators: The current work attributes a simpler or more extreme position to the prior work than the prior work actually held
Complex arguments from the prior work are reduced to single claims or catchphrases in the current work
The current work quotes the prior work selectively in ways that obscure important qualifications or counterarguments
The current work presents as continuous with the prior work while quietly reversing or contradicting key claims
The current work uses the prior work as a foil or negative example in ways that seem ungenerous or inaccurate

intellectual_grounding.method: Said's account of how theories change as they travel between contexts—often losing their critical edge and becoming domesticated—illuminates how an author's own concepts can be distorted in transit between their works. The capability treats each instance of self-appropriation as a case of traveling theory, asking what gets lost, simplified, or vulgarized as ideas move through the author's corpus.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete recombination analysis cataloguing all synthetic moves, tracing source elements to specific locations in prior works, assessing novelty and compatibility, analyzing acknowledgment status, and characterizing the author's recombinatory style (synthesizer/bricoleur/system-builder)
depth_scaling.standard: Maps all identifiable recombinations with source elements specified, assessment of genuine novelty vs. rearrangement, and analysis of compatibility or tensions between recombined elements
depth_scaling.surface: Notes obvious cases where the current work combines previously separate elements from the prior work

capabilities.description: Identify new combinations of old ideas and assess whether they produce genuine novelty or rearrangement
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability identifies moments where the author synthesizes elements from different sources—including different parts of the prior work, or elements from the prior work combined with material from other sources—into new configurations. Drawing on Lévi-Strauss's concept of bricolage and Latour's actor-network theory, it recognizes that intellectual creativity often consists not in generating entirely new concepts but in recombining existing elements in productive ways. The capability distinguishes genuine novelty (where recombination produces emergent properties that exceed the sum of parts) from mere rearrangement (where elements are shuffled without fundamental transformation). It tracks the source elements of each recombination, assesses compatibility (do the recombined elements fit together smoothly or create productive tensions?), and evaluates whether the author acknowledges the recombinatory nature of their innovation. In self-genealogy, recombination reveals how authors build on their own foundations: cumulative thinkers tend to recombine elements from multiple prior works into increasingly complex syntheses, while dialectical thinkers may recombine elements in ways that generate contradictions they then work to resolve.

Recombination analysis depends on migration_paths (you must track where elements came from) but adds a synthetic dimension: not just where concepts moved but how they were combined with others. It complements semantic_mutations (which tracks change) by tracking assembly and composition. The capability feeds into the broader question of intellectual development: is this author's trajectory one of progressive synthesis (building ever-larger structures from prior elements) or iterative exploration (recombining the same basic elements in different ways)? The sophistication lies in recognizing that recombination operates at multiple levels—concepts can be recombined, but so can methods, metaphors, and argumentative structures. Some recombinations are explicitly thematized (the author announces their synthetic ambitions), while others are implicit (the synthesis happens in practice without being named).
indicators: The current work brings together concepts from the prior work that were previously treated in separate chapters or sections
Arguments from the prior work are combined with theoretical frameworks or empirical material from other sources
The current work synthesizes distinctions or taxonomies from the prior work in new ways
Methodological approaches from the prior work are applied to new domains or combined with new techniques
The current work explicitly announces a synthetic ambition (e.g., 'bringing together my earlier work on X with recent developments in Y')

intellectual_grounding.method: Latour's actor-network theory shows how innovation consists in reconfiguring networks of associations between heterogeneous elements. This capability treats each new work as a reconfiguration of the network established in prior works, tracing which elements are carried forward, which new elements are introduced, and how their reassembly produces (or fails to produce) novelty.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete acknowledgment analysis classifying every borrowing's citation status, analyzing patterns (what determines citation?), correlating with distortion and appropriation patterns, interpreting strategic logic, and assessing what the acknowledgment pattern reveals about the author's self-relation and intellectual identity management
depth_scaling.standard: Maps acknowledgment status for all identified borrowings (cited/uncited/partially-cited), hypothesizes reasons for non-acknowledgment patterns, and assesses whether citation practices serve the author's rhetorical goals
depth_scaling.surface: Notes whether major borrowings are cited or uncited in a basic binary classification

capabilities.description: Map citation patterns: what is cited vs. suppressed, and what the pattern reveals about the author's self-relation
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability maps the politics of self-citation: which borrowings from the prior work are explicitly acknowledged through citation or reference, which are silently incorporated, and what logic governs these decisions. Drawing on Bourdieu's sociology of intellectual fields, it recognizes that citation is not merely a neutral scholarly practice but a strategic act within an economy of credit, authority, and positioning. Authors choose which prior work to reference in ways that serve their current rhetorical and institutional goals: citing establishes continuity and builds on accumulated authority, while suppressing citations can create the appearance of novelty, distance the author from positions they now reject, or conceal contradictions. In self-genealogy, these dynamics become particularly interesting because the author controls both the cited and citing text—they are simultaneously creditor and debtor, and their citation decisions reveal how they wish to be read, which aspects of their intellectual history they embrace versus which they obscure.

This capability synthesizes migration_paths (what was borrowed) and appropriation_patterns (how it was used) into an analysis of acknowledgment politics. It reveals correlations: do suppressed borrowings tend to be distorted ones? Are faithful appropriations more likely to be cited than adapted ones? The capability also performs counterfactual analysis: how would the current work be read differently if all debts were acknowledged? This exposes what the citation pattern accomplishes rhetorically. The sophistication lies in recognizing that acknowledgment operates on a spectrum—partial citation (referencing the prior work but understating the extent of borrowing), qualified citation (citing while emphasizing discontinuity), and strategic non-citation (where absence is meaningful)—and that patterns of acknowledgment across multiple works reveal an author's characteristic stance toward their own intellectual history. Some authors are scrupulous self-citers, others are strategic suppressors, and these styles of self-relation shape how their corpus coheres or fragments.
indicators: The current work makes claims or uses concepts that clearly derive from the prior work but without citing it
Footnotes reference the prior work but in contexts that understate the depth or breadth of the borrowing
The current work cites some aspects of the prior work while leaving closely related contributions unmentioned
Patterns of selective citation where certain chapters, arguments, or periods of the prior work are referenced while others are passed over
The current work's bibliography includes the prior work but the text itself makes minimal or no reference to it despite conceptual continuities

intellectual_grounding.method: Bourdieu's analysis of intellectual fields shows how citation practices function as exchanges of symbolic capital, establishing positions within networks of recognition and authority. This capability treats self-citation as a form of capital management: authors invest in certain aspects of their past work (through citation) while divesting from others (through suppression), strategically curating their intellectual identity.

consumes_from.cross_domain_transfers: From concept_evolution -- domain crossings that may involve appropriation or distortion
consumes_from.dimensional_comparisons: From concept_evolution -- vocabulary/methodology/metaphor/framing comparisons providing the evidence base for appropriation analysis
consumes_from.foundational_patterns: From concept_evolution -- persistent thinking patterns that may be appropriated unconsciously
consumes_from.relationship_classification: From Pass 1.5 -- whether this prior work is direct_precursor, indirect_contextualizer, different_field_relevant, counter_position, or tangential
consumes_from.target_work_profile: From Pass 1 -- key ideas and vocabulary of the current work

shares_with.acknowledgment_patterns: Citation vs. suppression patterns revealing the politics of self-relation
shares_with.distortion_catalog: Specific distortions with type, motivation, and impact
shares_with.migration_evidence: Detailed concept migration paths showing how ideas traveled between works
shares_with.recombination_maps: How elements from the prior work were recombined with other sources

depth_levels.description: Identify the most obvious concept migrations and note whether they are cited or uncited, faithful or adapted

passes.description:
Identify the most obvious concept migrations between prior and
current work. For each migration, note the mechanism of travel
(cited, silently borrowed, absorbed) and whether the concept
was carried faithfully or adapted. Quick surface scan for the
3-5 clearest cases.
passes.label: Migration Discovery

depth_levels.suitable_for: Quick assessment, tangential prior works, preliminary scoping, works with minimal conceptual overlap

depth_levels.description: Map migration paths with mechanisms, classify semantic mutations by type, assess appropriation fidelity, identify distortions, and map acknowledgment patterns. Suitable for most genealogical analysis.

passes.description:
Trace all significant concept migrations between prior and
current work. For each migrated concept, map the mechanism of
travel (explicit citation, silent borrowing, unconscious
absorption, independent rediscovery) and detect semantic
mutations that occurred in transit — extensions, restrictions,
metaphorizations, distortions, and inversions. This establishes
the factual base for appropriation analysis.
passes.label: Migration Path Tracing

passes.description:
With migration paths and mutations mapped, assess how concepts
were appropriated — faithfully preserved, adapted for new
context, distorted for strategic purposes, or inverted against
original intent. Map distortions with type, motivation, and
impact assessment. Analyze acknowledgment patterns to reveal
the politics of self-citation: what is credited, what is
silently borrowed, and what strategic logic governs the choices.
passes.label: Appropriation & Acknowledgment Assessment

depth_levels.suitable_for: Most prior work comparisons, direct precursors, works with moderate conceptual overlap, standard genealogy analysis

depth_levels.description: Full Derridean iterability analysis: every concept migration traced with mechanism, semantic mutation classified and motivated, appropriation assessed for legitimacy, distortions catalogued with counterfactuals, recombinations mapped with novelty assessment, and acknowledgment patterns analyzed for strategic logic. Includes assessment of the author's characteristic appropriation style.

passes.description:
Exhaustive migration tracing. Every concept that appears in
both works traced with mechanism of travel, intermediate stops,
and contextual analysis. Every semantic mutation classified by
type and motivated — distinguishing strategic mutations (the
author deliberately changed the concept) from drift (meaning
shifted through changing context). Map the full migration
landscape between the two works.
passes.label: Comprehensive Migration Tracing

passes.description:
With the migration landscape established, analyze the
architecture of appropriation. Classify each appropriation
for fidelity and legitimacy with impact assessment on both
original and new contexts. Catalogue distortions with
counterfactuals — what would the concept mean if not distorted?
Map recombinations where elements from different prior works
or different parts of the same work are combined into novel
configurations, assessing whether recombination produces
genuine novelty or merely the illusion of it.
passes.label: Appropriation Architecture & Distortion Mapping

passes.description:
Full analysis of the politics of self-citation and the
author's characteristic appropriation style. Map what is
acknowledged versus suppressed and hypothesize the strategic
logic — embarrassment about prior positions, desire for
novelty, strategic distancing, or genuine forgetting. Assess
whether the overall appropriation pattern is faithful
inheritance, creative transformation, or strategic distortion.
Identify the author's signature appropriation style: do they
tend toward faithful preservation, creative adaptation, or
systematic rebranding?
passes.label: Acknowledgment Politics & Appropriation Style

depth_levels.suitable_for: The most important prior works, works with extensive conceptual overlap, cases where appropriation or distortion is central to the genealogical question, prolific authors with complex self-citation patterns

key_concepts.definition: Derrida's neologism combining 'difference' and 'deferral' to describe how meaning is never fully present but always constituted through differential relations and temporal delay. For this engine, differance explains why concepts necessarily change when appropriated into new contexts—each iteration differs from and defers the 'original' meaning, making perfect conceptual continuity between works impossible.
key_concepts.name: differance

key_concepts.definition: The structural necessity that for any sign to function it must be repeatable across different contexts, yet this repeatability ensures the sign will mean differently in each iteration. This engine uses iterability to analyze how self-citation necessarily involves semantic transformation: the 'same' concept appearing in multiple works is never truly the same, as the new context inevitably alters its significance.
key_concepts.name: iterability

key_concepts.definition: Said's concept describing how theories change as they migrate between intellectual contexts, losing some original complexity while gaining new emphases adapted to new settings and purposes. The engine applies this to intra-corpus migration, tracking how concepts are simplified, elaborated, or reoriented as they travel from earlier to later works within a single author's output.
key_concepts.name: traveling_theory

key_concepts.definition: Bakhtin's term for the coexistence of multiple social voices, perspectives, and meaning-systems within language, such that every utterance contains traces of diverse contexts and intentions. This engine uses heteroglossia to detect how an author's later work contains multiple, sometimes conflicting voices from their earlier positions, revealing self-appropriation as internally dialogic and often contradictory rather than seamlessly unified.
key_concepts.name: heteroglossia

key_concepts.definition: Bloom's theory that strong writers struggle with their precursors through creative misreading and strategic distortion to establish originality. Applied to self-relation, this concept helps the engine identify when authors defensively misread or strategically distance themselves from their own earlier work to assert novelty or manage embarrassing contradictions in their intellectual development.
key_concepts.name: anxiety_of_influence

key_concepts.definition: A productive distortion of a source text that enables creative transformation and the establishment of difference. For this engine, misreading names the strategic ways authors reinterpret their own earlier formulations—simplifying, exaggerating, or selectively quoting—to make past work serve present argumentative needs, whether to claim consistency, assert development, or construct a coherent intellectual narrative.
key_concepts.name: misreading

key_concepts.definition: The act of taking concepts, terms, or frameworks from one context and deploying them in another, necessarily involving transformation and re-signification. This engine tracks appropriation patterns to map how authors extract elements from their prior work and repurpose them, examining whether such borrowing is acknowledged, how much transformation occurs, and what interests drive the selective uptake of earlier material.
key_concepts.name: appropriation

key_concepts.definition: The changes in meaning, emphasis, connotation, or scope that concepts undergo as they are appropriated into new contexts. This engine maps semantic mutations to reveal how concepts evolve across an author's corpus—which dimensions get amplified, which fade, which new associations accrue—distinguishing acknowledged development from unacknowledged drift or distortion.
key_concepts.name: semantic_mutation

key_concepts.definition: The strategic choices authors make about whether and how to recognize their intellectual debts, continuities, and borrowings, shaped by interests in establishing novelty, authority, and coherent self-presentation. This engine analyzes acknowledgment politics to detect when authors explicitly mark conceptual inheritance from their earlier work versus when they appropriate without acknowledgment, and what such patterns reveal about their self-fashioning strategies and management of intellectual trajectory.
key_concepts.name: acknowledgment_politics

primary.description: Jacques Derrida (1930-2004), founder of deconstruction, demonstrated that concepts carry traces of their previous contexts and can never be perfectly transported into new settings without transformation. His analysis of iterability—the necessary mutation that occurs whenever a sign is repeated in a new context—provides the theoretical foundation for understanding how self-citation is always also self-alteration, making him essential for tracking how authors appropriate and inevitably distort their own prior work.
primary.name: derrida

secondary.description: Edward Said (1935-2003), postcolonial theorist who developed the concept of 'traveling theory' to describe how ideas change as they move between intellectual and cultural contexts. His work extends Derrida's insights by emphasizing that conceptual migration is never neutral—theories acquire new emphases, lose original nuances, and serve different political purposes in their new homes, providing this engine with a framework for analyzing the interests and power dynamics embedded in acts of conceptual appropriation.
secondary.name: said

secondary.description: Mikhail Bakhtin (1895-1975), Russian theorist of dialogism and heteroglossia, argued that every utterance is populated with the intentions of prior speakers and that language is always already appropriated from others. His concept of heteroglossia—the coexistence of multiple voices and meaning-systems within a single text—helps this engine detect how authors' later work ventriloquizes, transforms, or struggles with their own earlier positions, revealing self-citation as a form of internal dialogue fraught with tension and mutation.
secondary.name: bakhtin

secondary.description: Harold Bloom (1930-2019), literary critic whose theory of 'anxiety of influence' described how poets creatively misread their predecessors to carve out original space. His concept of misreading as creative distortion applies powerfully to self-appropriation: authors often strategically misread their own earlier work to establish novelty, manage contradictions, or assert a coherent intellectual trajectory, making Bloom's framework crucial for detecting patterns of self-distortion and strategic self-relation.
secondary.name: bloom

secondary.description: Pierre Bourdieu (1930-2002), sociologist who analyzed how intellectual production is shaped by struggles for authority, legitimacy, and symbolic capital within academic fields. His attention to the strategic interests governing citation practices, canon formation, and the presentation of intellectual lineage helps this engine understand why authors selectively appropriate their own work—which prior texts get cited, which get buried, and how self-citation functions as a form of symbolic self-positioning within disciplinary power structures.
secondary.name: bourdieu

traditions.description: An approach to textual analysis emphasizing that meaning is never stable or fully present, but always deferred through chains of supplementation and contaminated by traces of other contexts. Deconstruction reveals that concepts cannot be transplanted without transformation, providing this engine with the epistemological foundation for treating all conceptual migration—including self-appropriation—as necessarily involving semantic mutation, slippage, and the production of new differences.
traditions.name: deconstruction

traditions.description: An interdisciplinary tradition examining how knowledge, culture, and identity are shaped by colonial power relations and their afterlives, particularly attentive to processes of appropriation, translation, and the violence of decontextualization. Its sensitivity to how ideas change meaning when moved between centers and peripheries, and its critique of claims to neutral knowledge transfer, equips this engine to analyze the power dynamics and political stakes embedded in acts of conceptual migration, even within a single author's corpus.
traditions.name: postcolonial_theory

traditions.description: Bakhtin's theory that all language is fundamentally dialogic—shaped by prior utterances and oriented toward anticipated responses—and that meaning emerges from the interaction between multiple voices rather than from isolated speakers. This tradition allows the engine to treat an author's corpus as an internal dialogue where later works respond to, contest, and reaccentuate earlier positions, revealing self-appropriation as a form of heteroglossic struggle rather than simple continuity.
traditions.name: dialogism

traditions.description: A critical tradition examining how writers relate to their predecessors through patterns of borrowing, transformation, resistance, and anxiety. While traditionally focused on inter-author relations, its methods for detecting misreading, strategic distortion, and the creative transformation of source material prove equally powerful for analyzing intra-author relations, helping this engine map how authors appropriate, distort, and creatively misread their own earlier formulations to serve new argumentative purposes.
traditions.name: influence_studies

traditions.description: An approach analyzing how knowledge production is shaped by social positions, institutional contexts, field-specific logics, and struggles for recognition and authority. This tradition reveals that citation practices—including self-citation—are never purely intellectual but always also strategic acts of positioning, making visible the career interests, disciplinary pressures, and authority-building projects that shape which concepts authors carry forward, which they abandon, and how they represent their own intellectual trajectories.
traditions.name: sociology_of_knowledge

problematique:
Concepts do not stay where they were born. They migrate between
contexts, mutate as they travel, get appropriated by new users,
distorted by new purposes, and recombined into configurations their
originators never imagined. When an author builds on their own prior
work, every act of self-citation is also an act of self-appropriation:
the author takes an idea from one context (the prior work) and places
it in another (the current work), and in that transit, the idea changes.

This engine tracks that transit. Building on the dimensional comparisons
produced by concept_evolution (the first engine in the scanning chain),
it adds the appropriation layer: not just HOW concepts changed between
works, but the dynamics of that change. Was a concept faithfully
carried forward, or was it adapted to serve a new purpose? Was the
adaptation acknowledged, or was continuity asserted where change
occurred? Were ideas borrowed from the author's own earlier work
without acknowledgment -- and if so, why? Were they distorted in
transit -- simplified, strawmanned, selectively quoted?

The appropriation lens reveals the politics of self-relation. Authors
are not neutral custodians of their own ideas. They have interests:
establishing novelty (downplaying continuity), asserting consistency
(downplaying change), building authority (curating which prior work
to reference), and managing contradictions (burying inconvenient
earlier positions). This engine maps those dynamics.

It is the SECOND engine in the prior work scanning chain (Pass 2).
It runs once per prior work, consuming concept_evolution's output and
adding migration paths, semantic mutations, appropriation patterns,
distortion maps, recombination analysis, and acknowledgment status.
researcher_question: How have concepts migrated and mutated across contexts?
